newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU states must vet U.S. gene-modified corn imports.
newsitem.headline: EU states must vet U.S. gene-modified corn imports.

text.p: European Union member states will have to check this year's U.S. maize imports for gene-modified strains which are not authorised for sale in the bloc, raising the prospect of further bilateral trade friction.
"European member states have to ensure...that (unauthorised maize) is not put on to the market on their territory," a European Commission spokesman told reporters on Wednesday.

A U.S. farm official in Brussels said it was tricky to spot the difference between genetically engineered and normal maize and added that gene-modified products from this year's harvest might end up going for export.
"We have no means of guaranteeing it won't get into export channels," the official told Reuters.
U.S. maize exports to the EU were worth $530 million in 1995/96 when world prices were very high. Exports are normally worth $300 million, the official said.
"We don't know if there will be a trade problem...but it has the potential to be really ugly," the official added.
The Commission spokesman played down suggestions that checks were impractical or risked sparking an EU-U.S. row similar to the one on U.S. hormone-treated beef exports.
"To say it's the start of a trade war is to put the cart before the horse," he said, adding that most U.S. imports comprised unmodified grains which would face no barriers.
"(EU countries) will have to ensure that they comply with the EU legislation for the residual amount.

News of the checks, which will kick in once imports of this year's U.S. harvest arrive in Europe, came as the EU grapples with a French request to allow the sale of a genetically-modified maize produced by Swiss company Ciba-Geigy on EU markets.
Ciba's "Zea mays L" maize strain, which has U.S. clearance, has modified properties intended to repel the corn borer pest and to increase its tolerance to certain weed killers.

France sought approval for the strain earlier this year, a request supported by the Commission in its proposal COM(96)206. This failed to get qualified majority support in the member state committee responsible for decisions under Directive 90/220/EEC.

Failure here meant the dossier passed to the Environment Council in June, where ministers also failed to reach a conclusion, prompting the Commission to refer the matter to the scientific committees on foodstuffs, pesticides and animal nutrition for their advice.
The Commission said its referral to the committees was justified on the grounds that new scientific evidence had been presented by Austria.
Ministers' questions related to concerns about product labelling and the effects of the maize on human health and the environment.

The three scientific committees are now to review the file and report back to Commission "within several months", the Commission spokesman said, adding that this would be either at the end of October or November.

The repeated delays highlight the confusion raised by legal services' interpretation of the commitology procedure as it relates to Article 21 of 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release of genetically modified organisms into the environment.

Officials' interpretations of those rules, namely procedure IIIa, have raised the legal absurdity that rejection or amendment of an approval request is well-nigh impossible by the Council of Ministers once a file has failed to get the necessary majority in committee.
Ministers can reject the Commission proposal only unanimously, an unlikely prospect given that one of them will have sponsored the original request.
Procedure IIIb would allow rejection by a simple majority.

The spokesman said the current rules were due for a review which, given the problems which have occurred, could turn into a proposal for a new directive. The review was not due to conclude before the end of the year, he said.
